awd_titl_txt: Expanding Pathways into Computer Science Across South Dakota
awd_abstract_narration:
Black Hills State University (BHSU) proposes a project--Expanding Pathways into Computer Science across South Dakota (EPCS-SD)--that builds on a current pilot project, extending its reach to profoundly rural regions and under-served students throughout the state.  The project will test and refine the pilot project's professional development program, focusing on the nationally disseminated high school curriculum Exploring Computer Science (ECS), in a statewide setting. The program will be modified to support a more geographically distributed group of teachers, the curriculum will be enhanced with additional local relevance and cultural connections important to American Indian communities, and new student recruitment and family engagement strategies will be implemented.

The project will develop a Research Practitioner Partnership with a number of partners: teachers and administrators from 20 South Dakota schools; faculty from BHSU and South Dakota School of Mines and Technology; South Dakota GEAR UP (Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs), a joint effort of BHSU and South Dakota's Office of Indian Education; and a nonprofit, Technology and Innovation in Education.  The research questions will evolve based on the needs of the practitioners but are expected to focus on the extent to which the PD program succeeds in equipping teachers to teach ECS effectively: To what degree does the suite of PD components--together with the ECS curriculum itself--build teacher confidence and competence in teaching computer science? and To what degree does participation in the ECS course influence student beliefs and attitudes?
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Expanding Pathways into Computer Science Across South Dakota (EPCS-SD) project engaged 50 high school teachers from 41 schools and 37 districts in implementing the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum. This 6-year effort built on a pilot project that served a more limited number of schools and teachers (DRL-1441080), broadening its reach across the entire state. Through the two projects combined, a total of 74 teachers from 53 schools and 48 districts participated. Over 30% of South Dakota's public high schools had at least one teacher participate, and one third of the South Dakota's non-public high schools that serve primarily Native American students (US Bureau of Indian Education, Tribal, and private schools) had at least one teacher participate.

EPCS-SD succeeded in engaging teachers, schools, and districts that serve the most rural regions of the state and regions with high populations of Native American students. The project also succeeded in creating a robust network of high school teachers who support one another in teaching computer science. 

Professional development components included in-person summer institutes and academic-year gatherings, virtual professional learning opportunities, in-classroom support, and remote video coaching. This array of strategies was successful in addressing the widespread geographic distribution of participating teachers.

Teachers and project personnel learned with and from one another using a research-practice partnership approach. Research findings appear in Sayler, B., Her Many Horses, I., Kertzman, D., Belden, T., Carroll, B., and H. Caffee (2021). Introducing computer science within South Dakota high schools through a research-practice partnership: Exploring student enrollment, attitudes, and problem-solving with a focus on broadening participation. In CSforAll & Sage Fox Consulting (Eds.), The intersection of RPPs and BPC in CS education: A compendium of papers from the RPPforCS community [White Paper], CSEdResearch.org. DOI:10.13140/RG.2.2.30216.96009

Inverness Research served as external evaluator. Their summative report included the following findings:

  • The project successfully resulted in more widespread implementation of the ECS curriculum across the state of South Dakota.
  • The project's research led to important findings about gender differences in computer science and problem solving that are continuing to be explored through additional grant funding (DRL-2031526).
  • The project developed important teacher leadership capacity to implement the ECS curriculum and also to support professional development for other teachers. 
  • The project adapted the professional development and curriculum for the South Dakota context.
  • Students had positive experiences in the ECS classes and gained problem-solving skills and confidence in doing computer science work.

 


Last Modified: 01/27/2024
Modified by: Bentley Sayler
